case_name: R. K. Dalmia, R. P. Gurha, L. Chokhani and Vishnu Prasad v. Respondents

facts.text: These three appeals are by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 2, 1961, of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Delhi Appeal Nos. 7 to 9 of 1961. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 2, 1961, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Criminal Appeals Nos. 464-C, 465-C and 463--D of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal No. 7 of 1961 is by R. K. Dalmia.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 7 of 1961 is by R. K. Dalmia. Appeal No. 8 of 1961 is by R.P.Gurha. Appeal No. 9 of 1961 is by L.Chokhani and Vishnu Prasad.

facts.text: All the appellants were convicted of the offence under s. 120 read with s.409 P.C.

anchor.surface_text: All the appellants were companyvicted of the offence under s. 120 read with s.409 P.C., and all of them, except Vishnu Prasad, were also companyvicted of certain offences arising out of the overt acts companymitted by them.

facts.text: Dalmia and Chokhani were convicted under s. 409 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Dalmia and Chokhani were companyvicted under s. 409 I.P.C. Chokhani was also companyvicted under s. 477A read with s. 110, I. P. C.

facts.text: Gurha was convicted under s. 477A P. C.

anchor.surface_text: Gurha was companyvicted under s. 477A P. C. To appreciate the case against the appellants, we may first state generally the facts leading to the case.

facts.text: Bharat Insurance Company was incorporated in 1896.

anchor.surface_text: Bharat Insuirance Company was incorporated in 1896. In 1936, Dalmia purchased certain shares of the companypany and became a Director and Chairman of the companypany.

facts.text: In 1936, Dalmia purchased certain shares of the company and became a Director and Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: In 1936, Dalmia purchased certain shares of the companypany and became a Director and Chairman of the companypany. He resigned from these offices in 1942 and was succeeded by his brother J. Dalmia.

facts.text: The head office of the Bharat Insurance Company was shifted from Lahore to 10, Daryaganj, Delhi in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The head office of the Bharat Insurance Company was shifted from Lahore to 10, Daryaganj, Delhi. in 1947. Dalmia was companyopted a Director on March 1.0, 1949

facts.text: Dalmia was co-opted a Director on March 10, 1949 and was again elected Chairman on March 19, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Dalmia was companyopted a Director on March 1.0, 1949 and was again elected Chairman of the companypany on March 19, 1949 when his brother J. Dalmia resigned.

facts.text: The period of criminal conspiracy charged against the appellant is from August 1954 to September 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The period of criminal companyspiracy charged against the appellant is from August 1954 to September 1955. Dalmia was therefore, during the relevant period, both Chairman and Principal Officer

facts.text: Dalmia was appointed Principal Officer with effect from August 20, 1954 and remained Chairman and Principal Officer till September 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Dalmia was appointed Principal Officer of the companypany with effect from August 20, 1954. He remained the Chairman and Principal Officer of the Company till September 22, 1955.

facts.text: During relevant period, company had current account in Chartered Bank at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: During this relevant period, this companypany had its current account in the Chartered Bank of India, Australia and China Ltd.  hereinafter called the Chartered Bank  at Bombay.

facts.text: On January 31, 1951, Board authorized Chokhani to operate on the account.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1951, the Board of Directors of the Insurance Company passed resolutions to the following effect  1  To open an account in the Chartered Bank at Bombay.  2  To authorise Chokhani

facts.text: Chokhani was appointed Agent of the company at Bombay on January 31, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day Chokhani was appointed Agent of the companypany at Bombay. He was its agent during the relevant period.

facts.text: From October 1, 1953, account operated jointly by Chokhani and Raghunath Rai.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1953, the Board of Directors directed that the current account of the companypany with the Chartered Bank, Bombay, be operated jointly by Chokhani and Raghunath Rai, P.W. 4.

facts.text: Chokhani purchased and sold securities under instructions of Dalmia (prosecution case).

anchor.surface_text: Chokhani was number empowered by any resolution of the Board of Directors to purchase and sell securities. According to the prosecution, he purchased and sold securities under the instructions of Dalmia.

facts.text: Bhagwati Trading Company owned by Vishnu Prasad, nephew of Chokhani.

anchor.surface_text: Chokhani entered into a transaction of purchase of securities with a broker. The broker entered into a transaction of purchase of the same securities from a companypany named Bhagwati Trading Company which was owned by Vishnu Prasad, appellant, nephew of Chokhani

facts.text: Funds of Insurance Company diverted to Bharat Union Agencies via Bhagwati Trading Company without delivery of securities.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the amount of the cheques was paid out of the companypanys funds without any gain to it. The sale transactions companysisted in the sale of the securities held or supposed to be held by the companypany

facts.text: Bharat Union Agencies suffered losses in relevant period August 1954 to September 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Union Agencies suffered Icsses in the relevant period from August 1954 to September, 1955. The prosecution case is that to provide funds for the payment of these losses at the due time,

facts.text: Bharat Union Agencies practically owned by Dalmia.

anchor.surface_text: Bharat Union Agencies   hereinafter referred to as the Union Agencies  was a companypany which dealt in speculation in shares and, according to the prosecution was practically owned by Dalmia

facts.text: Government appointed Shri K. Annadhanam on September 19, 1955 to investigate under s.33(1) Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: Shri K. Annadhanam  Chartered Accountant, appointed by the Government of India on September 19, 1955, to investigate into the affairs of the Bharat Insurance Company under s. 33  1  of the Insurance Act

facts.text: Learned Sessions Judge convicted appellants; High Court substantially agreed except not relying on Dalmia's confession.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge found the offences charged against the appellants proved on the basis of the circumstances established in the case and, accordingly, companyvicted them as stated above. The High Court substantially agreed

facts.text: Dalmia's defence: authorised Chokhani in 1953 to purchase/sell securities on own; no knowledge of modus operandi.

anchor.surface_text: Dalmias defence, in brief, is that be had numberhing to do with the details of the working of the companypany, that he had authorised Chokhani, in 1953, to purchase and sell securities and that thereafter Chokbani on his own

facts.text: Chokhani admits transactions to meet Union Agencies losses, thought it was loan.

anchor.surface_text: Chokhani admits that he carried out the transactions in the form alleged in order to meet the losses of the Union Agencies of which he was an employee. He states that be did so as he expected

facts.text: On August 9, 1954, Chokhani purchased securities worth Rs.22,00,000 on behalf of Insurance Co. from brokers, cross-sold via Bhagwati.

anchor.surface_text: On August 9, 1954, Chokbani purchased 3 1963-65 securities of the face value of Rs. 22,00,000 on behalf of the Insurance Company from Naraindas and Sons, Security Brokers. Chokhani entered, into a cross-contract

holdings.text: The Delhi Court had jurisdiction to try Chokhani for the offence under s. 409 I.P.C. as the offence was alleged to have been committed in pursuance of the criminal conspiracy, following Purushottam Das Dalmia v. State of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: This Court held in Purushotam Das Dalmia v. State of West Bengal that the Court having jurisdiction to try the offence of conspiracy has also jurisdiction to try an offence constituted by the overt acts

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent that conspiracy jurisdiction extends to overt acts committed beyond territorial limits; no need for reconsideration.

holdings.text: The second and third contentions regarding misjoinder of charges do not arise for consideration once jurisdiction is upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this opinion, the second and third contentions do not arise for consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dependent on rejection of jurisdiction challenge; curability under ss.531-537 not reached.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.233 CrPC requires separate charges for distinct offences; here single offence of criminal breach of trust via various modes, no prejudice shown.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Property' wider than movable property per s.22 IPC; bank funds are chose in action; distinguishes/rejects cases limiting to movables like Reg. v. Girdhar.

holdings.text: Dalmia, as Chairman and Principal Officer, had dominion over company funds in Bombay bank despite bank not informed of his authority.

anchor.surface_text: It is further contended for Dalmia that he had not been entrusted with dominion over the funds in the Banks at Bombay and had no control over them

holdings.text: Bye-laws Exhibit P-786 are genuine and empower Chairman to deal with securities and funds.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit P-786 is said to be the original Byelaws passed by the Directors on September 8, 1951. The pages are signed by K.L. Gupta, who was the General Manager

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proved by Gupta's testimony, copies to bank/auditor certified by Dalmia (P-896/897), no reason for falsity.

holdings.text: Dalmia and Chokhani are 'agents' under s.409 IPC; 'in the way of his business as agent' includes entrustment in course of duties as Chairman/Director and appointed Agent.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is that Dalmia and Chokhani were not agents as contemplated by s. 409 I. P. C. The contention is that the word agent in this Section

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets 'agent' broadly to include company positions where entrustment occurs in course of business/duties; distinguishes Portugal/Cooray as not requiring profession of agency.

holdings.text: Joint dominion over funds (with Raghunath Rai) sufficient for Chokhani to commit criminal breach of trust under s.409; practice gave effective control.

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged for Chokhani that he could not have committed the offence of criminal breach of trust when he alone had not the dominion over the funds

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Calcutta FB and Bombay HC; distinguishes Bindeshwari (no joint dominion issue); blank signed cheques conferred effective control.

holdings.text: Appellants guilty of conspiracy u/s 120B r/w s.409 and substantive offences; defences rejected; evidence of Raghunath Rai reliable and corroborated.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings; circumstantial evidence (modus operandi, calls, instructions, no delivery of securities, diversion to Union Agencies) proves dishonest intent/knowledge beyond doubt.
